DOC.brief_title: Assessment Two Postoperative Techniques Used Predict Voiding Efficiency After Gynecologic Surgery
DOC.detailed_description: Postoperative void dysfunction commonly encounter follow gynecologic surgery . This dysfunction usually short term , normal function return within day . Following uro/gynecologic surgery , patient require drainage either transurethral suprapubic catheter immediate postoperative period . Within practice , prefer drainage transurethral catheter . At point surgery , urethral catheter remove normal bladder function allow resume . At present , generally accept regimen ass void efficiency . In practice , currently employ two regimen ass void efficiency expedite catheter removal . In one technique , catheter remove patient 's bladder allow fill spontaneously . Patients ask void experience strong urge . The voided volume record post-void residual ( PVR ) measure transurethral straight catheterization . In second technique , patient 's bladder retrogradely fill 300 cc sterile fluid catheter remove . They ask void within 15 minute instillation void volume measure . The PVR obtain transurethral straight catheterization . In case , patient void > 2/3 total volume ( voided volume + residual ) trial consider `` pass '' catheter remove . If patient void < 2/3 total volume , trial consider `` failed '' indicative urinary retention . In case catheter replace . We aim assess ability technique accurately predict void efficiency determine one technique superior .
DOC.criteria: All woman > 18 year age present Division Urogynecology University Rochester Medical Center/Strong Memorial Hospital undergo gynecologic surgery require postoperative placement transurethral catheter . Subjects must competent give inform consent . Any patient less 18 year age . Patients suprapubic catheter postoperatively . Patients undergoing surgery require transurethral catheterization postoperatively . Patients competent give inform consent . Patients pregnant . Patients undergoing procedure require prolonged bladder decompression ( i.e . fistula repair ) .
